headline.print_headline: Mideast Terrorism: The Qatar Government’s View

snippet: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
abstract: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American natural gas by converting giant Golden Pass terminal in Sabine Pass, Tex, to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion; is partnering with Exxon Mobile in effort to export sizable share of the new American bonanza.

headline.main: A U-Turn for a Terminal Built in Texas to Import Natural Gas
headline.print_headline: A U-Turn for a Terminal Built to Import Natural Gas

snippet: Representative Frank R. Wolf wrote a letter to the Brookings Institution this week saying that think tanks that provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking donations from some foreign governments.
lead_paragraph: Representative Frank R. Wolf wrote a letter to the Brookings Institution this week saying that think tanks that provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking donations from some foreign governments.
abstract: Rep Frank R Wolf, Republican of Virginia, writes letter to president of Brookings Institution saying that prominent Washington think tanks that routinely provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking foreign government donations; Brookings collects about 12 percent of its annual budget from foreign governments.

headline.main: Lawmaker Assails Foreign Donations to Think Tanks
headline.print_headline: Lawmaker Assails Foreign Giving to Think Tanks

snippet: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’...
lead_paragraph: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’ priorities, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
abstract: New York Times investigation finds that more than dozen prominent Washington research groups have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments in recent years while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect donors' priorities; money is increasingly transforming once-staid think-tank world into muscular arm of foreign governments' lobbying in Washington.

headline.main: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks
headline.print_headline: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks

snippet: While partners like Sony and Adidas raised concerns before the World Cup, it is unlikely that sponsor companies will risk undermining their investment in the FIFA brand.
lead_paragraph: While partners like Sony and Adidas raised concerns before the World Cup, it is unlikely that sponsor companies will risk undermining their investment in the FIFA brand.
abstract: Corporate sponsors of FIFA like Sony and Adidas raised concerns about accusations of corruption before 2014 World Cup began in June, but now that soccer matches are over, it is unlikely that they will demand reforms and risk undermining their big investments in FIFA brand.

headline.main: With Huge Sums in Play, FIFA Sponsors Are Reluctant to Push Reforms
headline.print_headline: With Huge Sums in Play, FIFA Sponsors Are Reluctant to Push Reforms

snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said that Muslim Brotherhood leaders could be granted entry to Turkey as long as laws permitted.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said that Muslim Brotherhood leaders could be granted entry to Turkey as long as laws permitted.
abstract: Turkish Pres Recep Tayyip Erdogan says that several exiled leaders of Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood who fled to Qatar can perhaps find refuge in his country.

headline.main: Turkey Open to Bids for Refuge by Muslim Brotherhood Exiles
headline.print_headline: Turkey Open to Bids for Refuge by Muslim Brotherhood Exiles

snippet: Krishna Upadhyaya, a researcher, and Ghimire Gundev, a photographer, had been reported missing on Aug. 31, that same day they were preparing to leave the country.”
lead_paragraph: Krishna Upadhyaya, a researcher, and Ghimire Gundev, a photographer, had been reported missing on Aug. 31, that same day they were preparing to leave the country.”
abstract: Authorities in Qatar confirm that British citizens Krishna Upadhyaya and Ghimire Gundev, who went missing while researching migrant labor issues, have been arrested and are being interrogated for having violated provisions of Qatari laws.

headline.main: Officials in Qatar Confirm Detention of Britons Researching Migrant Labor
headline.print_headline: Officials in Qatar Confirm Detention of Britons Researching Migrant Labor

snippet: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
lead_paragraph: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
abstract: Qatar has come under withering attack from wide spectrum of interests who insist that tiny monarchy is a godfather to terrorist causes worldwide; country has helped support a number of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and even weapons, and allows private fund-raisers for terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda to freely operate within its territory.

headline.main: Qatar’s Support of Islamists Alienates Allies Near and Far
headline.print_headline: Qatar’s Support of Extremists Alienates Allies Near and Far

keywords.name: organizations

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Mohamad Adam and Merna Thomas from Cairo, Isabel Kershner from Jerusalem and Fares Akram from Gaza.

snippet: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
abstract: Tiny gulf nation of Qatar, lacking enough young players to form national soccer team, began ambitious program to identify and train talent from Africa as it sought to build credibility as host of 2022 World Cup; Qatar says program is humanitarian venture, though there is some concern country may nationalize some of players (Series: Seeding the Field).

headline.main: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad
headline.print_headline: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad

byline.contributor: Steve Eder reported from Doha, Qatar; Sam Borden from Eupen, Belgium; and Christopher Harress and Jack Williams from New York.
byline.original: By STEVE EDER, SAM BORDEN, CHRISTOPHER HARRESS and JACK WILLIAMS

snippet: Qatar’s lavish support of Hamas is the biggest obstacle to a deal on Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Qatar’s lavish support of Hamas is the biggest obstacle to a deal on Gaza.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Ron Prosor, Israel's ambassador to the United Nations, holds Qatar's lavish support of Hamas represents the single biggest obstacle to a peace agreement in Gaza; contends the oil-rich gulf state has been using its vast wealth to leverage influence and destabilize rivals, choosing radical groups like Hamas as proxies; calls on global community to isolate Qatar until it revises its tactics.

headline.main: Club Med for Terrorists
headline.print_headline: Club Med for Terrorists

snippet: The Obama administration has insisted that it told the government of Qatar not to pay a ransom for the release of the captured journalist Peter Theo Curtis.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has insisted that it told the government of Qatar not to pay a ransom for the release of the captured journalist Peter Theo Curtis.
abstract: Obama administration says that it brought family of American hostage Peter Theo Curtis together with government of Qatar in effort to secure his release, but insists it told Qataris not to pay a ransom for captured journalist.

headline.main: U.S. Says It Told Qatar Not to Pay a Ransom
headline.print_headline: U.S. Says It Told Qatar Not to Pay a Ransom

snippet: Peter Theo Curtis was freed after extensive mediation by Qatar, which has negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages.
lead_paragraph: Peter Theo Curtis was freed after extensive mediation by Qatar, which has negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages.
abstract: American freelance writer Peter Theo Curtis is unexpectedly freed by the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda affiliate in Syria; release follows extensive mediation by Qatar, and raises further questions about what, if any, concessions should be made to militant groups holding Western nationals.

headline.seo: Peter Theo Curtis, Abducted in 2012, Is Released by Nusra Front
headline.main: U.S. Writer Held by Qaeda Affiliate in Syria Is Freed After Nearly 2 Years
headline.print_headline: Qaeda Affiliate Frees American It Held in Syria

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by C.J. Chivers from the United States, Rick Gladstone from New York, Michael R. Gordon from Washington, Ben Hubbard from Baghdad, and Karam Shoumali from Istanbul.

snippet: In 2012, Aspire, bankrolled by Qatar’s royal family, acquired K.A.S. Eupen, a lower-division team in Belgium, as a place for its top players.

snippet: American forces took advantage of the strikes against the Islamic State in Syria to try to also wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell that the White House said was plotting against the United States or Europe.
lead_paragraph: American forces took advantage of the strikes against the Islamic State in Syria to try to also wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell that the White House said was plotting against the United States or Europe.
abstract: American forces take advantage of airstrikes against Islamic State extremist group in Syria to try and simultaneously wipe out leadership of Khorasan, unrelated cell of veterans of Al Qaeda; Obama administration says group was plotting 'imminent' attack against the United States or Europe.

headline.main: In Airstrikes, U.S. Targets Militant Cell Said to Plot an Attack Against the West
headline.print_headline: In Airstrikes, U.S. Targets Cell Said to Plot an Attack

snippet: The State Department asked Qatar to lift a travel ban against an American couple being held in connection with the death of their adopted daughter.
lead_paragraph: The State Department asked Qatar to lift a travel ban against an American couple being held in connection with the death of their adopted daughter.
abstract: United States calls on Qatar to lift travel ban on Matthew and Grace Huang, American couple held since January 2013 over death of their adopted African daughter; original charge of murder was thrown out, replaced by the lesser charge of child endangerment and a conviction in March that carries a three-year prison term and prohibition from leaving country.

headline.main: U.S. Seeks Release of Couple in Qatar, Creating Tensions With a Crucial Arab Ally
headline.print_headline: U.S. Seeks Release of Couple in Qatar, Creating Tensions With a Crucial Arab Ally

snippet: Rawabi, a heralded enterprise in the West Bank, lacks residents more than a year after its first 600 apartments were sold, becoming a cautionary tale about investing in the area.
lead_paragraph: Rawabi, a heralded enterprise in the West Bank, lacks residents more than a year after its first 600 apartments were sold, becoming a cautionary tale about investing in the area.
abstract: Rawabi, newly-constructed Palestinian city in the West Bank, remains empty of inhabitants more than a year after its first 600 apartments were sold; widely-heralded development project is stymied as it awaits approval from Israel to connect to a nearby water main, turning symbol of entrepreneurship into a cautionary tale about investing in the Israeli-occupied region.

headline.main: New Palestinian Town in West Bank Awaits Israel’s Approval for Water
headline.print_headline: New Palestinian Town in West Bank Awaits Israel’s Approval for Water

snippet: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
lead_paragraph: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
abstract: Rapid surge of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and its ability to draw fighters from across the globe, have set off alarm bells in capitals worldwide; countries that rarely see eye to eye are now trying to blunt its recruitment drive, passing a raft of new rules that they hope will stop their citizens from joining extremist groups abroad; United States is pushing for a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.

headline.main: Nations Trying to Stop Their Citizens From Going to Middle East to Fight for ISIS
headline.print_headline: Nations Working to Stop Citizens from Aiding ISIS

headline.main: Kerry Calls on Qatar and Turkey to Gain Release of Israeli Soldier

snippet: Peter Theo Curtis, who had been held captive for nearly two years by the Nusra Front, was released after the government of Qatar intervened on his behalf, his family said.
lead_paragraph: Peter Theo Curtis, who had been held captive for nearly two years by the Nusra Front, was released after the government of Qatar intervened on his behalf, his family said.
abstract: Peter Theo Curtis, American writer and freelance journalist held captive for nearly two years by Al Qaeda’s official branch in Syria, returns to the United States after the government of Qatar brokers his release

headline.main: Peter Theo Curtis, Released by Al Qaeda’s Syrian Branch, Flies Home to His Family
headline.print_headline: American Journalist, Released by Al Qaeda’s Syrian Branch, Flies Home to His Family

snippet: Plagued by endemic poverty, many young people in Nepal leave to work abroad. But the backbreaking labor they find there often results in death.
lead_paragraph: Plagued by endemic poverty, many young people in Nepal leave to work abroad. But the backbreaking labor they find there often results in death.
abstract: Many young people in Nepal are plagued by endemic poverty, and must leave the country to find work; large-scale emigration continues to grow, increasing 37 percent in just past two years; much of the work that emigrants find is backbreaking and dangerous manual labor, resulting in a troubling number of deaths.

headline.main: In Nepal, a Better Life With a Steep Price
headline.print_headline: In Nepal, a Better Life With a Steep Price

snippet: Through a program called Aspire Football Dreams, the Qataris had scouted hundreds of thousands of young African players; needing a place where the best youths could play professionally, they found it in a team in a small Belgian town.
lead_paragraph: Through a program called Aspire Football Dreams, the Qataris had scouted hundreds of thousands of young African players; needing a place where the best youths could play professionally, they found it in a team in a small Belgian town.
abstract: Executives from Qatar's Aspire Academy acquire KAS Eupen, Belgian soccer team; lure for Belgian team, on verge of financial ruin, is money; attraction for Academy executives is more complex; Qataris had scouted hundreds of thousands of young African players, since 2007, in hopes of bringing the best of them to academy for development as professional soccer players (Series: Seeding The Field).

headline.main: Qatari Soccer Empire Buys a Foothold in Europe
headline.print_headline: Qatari Soccer Empire Buys a Foothold in Europe

byline.contributor: Sam Borden reported from Eupen, Belgium; Steve Eder from Doha, Qatar; and Christopher Harress and Jack Williams from New York.
byline.original: By SAM BORDEN, STEVE EDER, JACK WILLIAMS and CHRISTOPHER HARRESS

lead_paragraph: The Qatari organisers for the 2022 World Cup are confident they will be exonerated in the independent investigation into the bidding process for the finals, one of their senior officials said on Tuesday.

headline.print_headline: Qatar Rejects Accusation It Sent Weapons to Libya

snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry will be leaning heavily on Egypt, Turkey and Qatar — which have deep divisions over the Islamic movement — to help broker a cease-fire as quickly as possible.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry will be leaning heavily on Egypt, Turkey and Qatar — which have deep divisions over the Islamic movement — to help broker a cease-fire as quickly as possible.
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry arrives in Egypt to try to produce cease-fire in Gaza crisis; Kerry must confront fact that United States must rely heavily on Egypt, Qatar and Turkey to play intermediary role and exert their influence because the US has no direct contact and little leverage with Hamas.

headline.main: To Talk With Hamas, U.S. Needs Help From a Testy Trio of Nations
headline.print_headline: To Talk With Hamas, U.S. Needs Help From a Testy Trio of Nations

headline.print_headline: Qatar Airways Takes Delivery of Its First Airbus A380

headline.print_headline: Qatar Regulates Charities After Western Concern Over Islamic State Funding

snippet: Qatar has asked seven senior figures from Egypt's outlawed Muslim Brotherhood to leave the country, the movement said on Saturday, following months of pressure on the Gulf Arab state from its neighbors to stop backing the Islamists.
lead_paragraph: Qatar has asked seven senior figures from Egypt's outlawed Muslim Brotherhood to leave the country, the movement said on Saturday, following months of pressure on the Gulf Arab state from its neighbors to stop backing the Islamists.
